name: Clark International Airport
description: Fort Stotsenberg, established in 1902, became Clark Air Field in 1919, named after aviator Major Harold Melville *C*la*r**k*. From 2003 to 2014, it was known as Diosdado Macapagal Airport.

name: Francisco Bangoy International Airport
description: Initially known as Sasa Landing Field, Davao International Airport began operations in the 1940s on land donated by Don Francisco Bangoy in Barangay Sasa, Buhangin district of *D*a*v*a*o* City. It was later renamed Francisco Bangoy Airport in his honor.

name: Iloilo International Airport
description: In 2006, as the airport project neared completion, three main contenders were considered for its name. However, after the airport opened, the original name, *I*loi*l**o* International Airport, was retained for its geographical value.

name: Kalibo International Airport
description: One of the busiest international airports in Western Visayas and one of the two serving Boracay, Kalibo International Airport caters to the general area of *K*a*l*ib*o*, the capital of Aklan province, hence its name.

name: Laoag International Airport
description: During the American colonial period, a military airfield was established in northern Luzon at *L**a**o*ag, the most populated settlement at the time. Originally known as Gabu Airfield, it was later renamed Laoag International Airport.

name: Mactan-Cebu Internation Airport
description: Built in 1956 as Mactan Air Base, Mactan-Cebu International Airport began domestic commercial operations in the 1960s and international charter flights in 1978. Located in Lapu-Lapu City, *C**e**b*u, it is the main gateway to Central Visayas in the Philippines.

name: Ninoy Aquino International Airport
description: In 1983, Senator Benigno "Ninoy" Aquino Jr. was assassinated at Manila International Airport. Years later, it was renamed Ninoy Aquino International Airport in his honor, and its airport code reflects the city it serves: *M*a*n*i*l*a.

name: Puerto Princesa International Airport
description: Constructed in 1942 by American prisoners of war for Japanese transport aircraft, Puerto Princesa Airport began serving air travel in 1947. Located in Palawan, it serves the *P*uerto *P*rince*s*a area and is the main gateway to the Puerto Princesa Underground River.

name: Bacolod-Silay Airport
description: Opened in 2008, Bacolod-Silay International Airport is located in Silay, Negros Occidental and serves greater Metro *B*a*c*olo*d*.

name: Bicol International Airport
description: Known as the Philippines' "Most Scenic Gateway," Bicol International Airport serves the Legazpi area in Albay and the regional center of the Bicol region. It is located in *D*a*r*aga, a neighboring municipality of Legaz*p*i.

name: Bohol-Panglao International Airport
description: To accommodate increased traffic from tourism, the province of Bohol replaced Tagbilaran Airport with a new facility in 2018, named Bohol-Panglao International Airport. The new airport retains the code from the previous name and serves as the gateway to *T**a**g*bilaran and the rest of Bohol.

name: Bancasi Airport
description: Situated in Bancasi Rotunda, Butuan, Bancasi Airport is the only airport in Agusan del Norte and the largest in the CARAGA region. Its three-letter code reflects the city it serves—*B**u*tuan—plus the filler letter '*x*'.

name: Cauayan Airport
description: Originally part of Nueva Vizcaya, Cauayan was transferred to Isabela on May 1, 1856, following a royal decree. The airport code reflects its history: *C*aua*y*an (formerly part of Nueva Vi*z*caya).

name: Cotobato Airport
local_name: Sambel-Dungguan su Kutawatu Paliparan ng Cotabato
city: Datu Odin Sinsuat, Maguindanao del Norte
description: Also known as Awang Airport, it is located in Barangay Awang, Maguindanao del Norte, and serves the general area of *C*ota*b*at*o* City, North Cotabato, Maguindanao del Norte, and Maguindanao del Sur.

name: Daniel Z. Romualdez Airport
description: Originally called San Jose Airstrip during World War II, the airport was later known as Tacloban National Airport, reflecting its location in *T**a**c*loban, Leyte. It was eventually renamed Daniel Z. Romualdez Airport, in honor of the Leyte representative and 10th Speaker of the House of Representatives.

name: Dipolog Airport
description: Dipolog Airport is one of the busiest airports in Mindanao, serving as the primary airport for the general area of *D*i*p*o*l*og, the capital city of Zamboanga del Norte.

name: Sibulan Airport
description: Sibulan Airport, located in Negros Oriental, serves the *D*uma*g*ue*t*e area and the surrounding regions. It offers both domestic flights and connections to major cities in the Philippines.

name: General Santos International Airport
local_name: Pangkalibutan nga Hulugpaan sang Heneral Santos
description: also known as Tambler Airport and General Santos City Airport, is an alternate international airport located in the city of General Santos, Philippines serving the greater area of Soccsksargen.

name: Godofredo P. Ramos International Airport
description: also known as Caticlan International Airport and recently, Boracay Airport by its developer Trans Aire, is an international airport serving the general area of the municipality of Malay, located in the province of Aklan in the Philippines

name: Labo Airport
description: also known as Ozamiz Airport, is an airport serving the general area of the city of Ozamiz in the Philippines. It is the only airport in the province of Misamis Occidental.

name: Laguindingan Airport
description: Laguindingan Airport, located in Misamis Oriental, serves the Cagayan de Oro area and surrounding regions. Its airport code, CGY, reflects its association with *C*a*g*a*y*an de Oro City.

name: Naga Airport
description: Naga Airport, situated in Pili, Camarines Sur, serves the city of Naga and its surrounding areas. Its airport code, WNP, reflects its connection to *N*aga and *P*ili in Camarines Sur, incorporating the letter '*W*' as a filler.

name: Pagadian Airport
description: Located in Pagadian City, Zamboanga del Sur. Facilitating air travel to and from the region. Its code is derived from the first three letters of *P**a**g*adian, reflecting its primary location and service area.

name: Roxas Airport
description: Roxas Airport is a domestic airport in Roxas City, Capiz, serving as a gateway to the Western Visayas region. Its code is derived from the name *R*o*x*a*s*, reflecting its location and service area.

name: Sanga-Sanga Airport
description: Sanga-Sanga Airport, situated in Bongao, Tawi-Tawi, Philippines, provides air travel services to the province. Its code is derived from *T*a*w*i-*T*awi, reflecting its primary location and service area.

name: San Jose Aiport
description: Originally known as McGuire Field during World War II and named after Major Thomas McGuire, San Jose Airport in Occidental Mindoro has the code "SJI," derived from the initials of *S*an *J*ose with an added filler letter '*I*.'

name: Subic Bay International Airport
local_name: Paliparang Pandaigdig ng Look ng Subic
description: Subic Bay International Airport has the code "SFS" because it stands for *S*ubic *F*reeport *S*huttle, reflecting its role in the Subic Bay Freeport Zone.

name: Tuguegarao Airport
description: Tuguegarao Airport is a domestic airport located in Tuguegarao City, Cagayan, Philippines, serving as a key gateway to the Cagayan Valley region. Derived from its name *T**u**g*uegarao, reflecting its primary location and service area.

name: Zamboanga International Airport
description: Originally known as Moret Field in 1945, Zamboanga International Airport is the primary airport serving *Z**a**m*boanga City and is the third busiest airport in Mindanao, following Davao (DVO) and Cagayan de Oro (CGY).

name: Basco Airport
description: Originally constructed in 1930 as Batan Airfield, Basco Airport now serves the province of Batanes. It is one of two airports on Batanes Island and is located in the provincial capital, *B*a*s*c*o*, from which its airport code is derived.

name: Calbayog Airport
description: Calbayog Airport, situated in Calbayog City, Samar, offers essential connectivity for the region. Its airport code, "CYP," comes from the city's name—*C*alba*y*og—with the letter '*P*' added as a filler, reflecting its location and service area.

name: Camiguin Airport
description: Camiguin Airport is located in Mambajao, Camiguin, serving the island province of Camiguin. Its airport code is derived from the name *C*a*m*i*g*uin, with the letters 'C', 'G', and 'M' representing the key components of the province's name.

name: Catarman National Airport
description: Catarman Airport is located in Catarman, Northern Samar, providing regional air connectivity. Its airport code is derived from the name *C*ata*r*ma*n*, reflecting its location and service area.
